statement.tex: %text Solve the differential equation \[ \qquad \cos^2 x\cdot \frac{dy}{dx} + y = \tan x \] %

\\ %text We will tell you that \[ \cos^2 x \cdot \frac{dy}{dx} + y = \tan x\] can be re-written as \[ \qquad\quad \frac{d}{dx}\left[ f(x)\cdot y \right] = \tan x \cdot \sec^2 x \cdot e^{\tan x}\]
\underline\text{But for what $f(x)$ will this be true}? %

\\ \begin{align} \text{Given that }\frac{d}{dx}\left[ e^{\tan x}\cdot y \right] &= e^{\tan x}\cdot\tan x\cdot \sec^2 x \\ \implies e^{\tan x}\cdot y &= \int e^z\cdot z\cdot dz \end{align} %text
then \underline\text{what is z in the above equation}? %
\\ %text What will \[ \int e^z\cdot z\cdot dz \] evaluate to in terms of x? And therefore, \underline\text{what will y be}? %

reason.tex:
%text $f(x)$ is what you know as the \underline\text{integrating} \underline\text{factor}. It allows us to \underline\text{re-write} a linear differential equation so that it can be solved easily. Now, % \begin{align} \cos^2 x \cdot\frac{dy}{dx} + y &= \tan x \\ \implies \frac{dy}{dx} + \underbrace{\sec^2 x}_{P(x)}\cdot y &= \underbrace{\tan x\cdot \sec^2 x}_{Q(x)} \end{align} %text
Therefore, the integrating factor $f(x)$ is \[ \qquad e^{\int P(x)\cdot dx} = e^{\int\sec^2x\cdot dx} = e^{\tan x }\]
And when we \underline\text{multiply both sides} with $f(x)$
% \begin{align} e^{\tan x}\frac{dy}{dx} + e^{\tan x}\cdot\sec^2 x\cdot y &= e^{\tan x}\cdot\tan x\cdot \sec^2 x \\ \text{Also, note that }\frac{d}{dx}e^{\tan x} &= e^{\tan x}\cdot\sec^2 x \\ \therefore \frac{d}{dx}\left[ e^{\tan x}\cdot y \right] &= e^{\tan x}\cdot\tan x\cdot \sec^2 x \end{align}

\begin{align} \frac{d}{dx} (e^{\tan x}\cdot y) &= e^{\tan x}\cdot\sec^2 x \cdot \tan x \\ \implies \int d (e^{\tan x}\cdot y) &= \int e^{\tan x}\cdot\sec^2 x \cdot \tan x \cdot dx \\ \implies e^{\tan x}\cdot y &= \int e^{\tan x}\cdot\sec^2 x \cdot \tan x \cdot dx \\ \text{Now, if }z = \tan x &\text{ then }dz = \sec^2 x \cdot dx \\ \therefore e^{\tan x}\cdot y &= \int e^z\cdot z\cdot dz \end{align}

\begin{align} \int e^z\cdot z\cdot dz &= \underbrace{z\int e^z\cdot dz - \int\left[ \frac{d}{dz}z\int e^z\cdot dz \right]dz}_{\text{Integration by parts}}\\ &= z\cdot e^z - \int \left(\int e^z\cdot dz\right)\cdot dz \\ &= z\cdot e^z - \int e^z\cdot dz = (z-1)\cdot e^z + C \\ &= \underbrace{(\tan x - 1)\cdot e^{\tan x}}_{z = \tan x} + C \\ \end{align} %text
And given that \[ \qquad e^{\tan x}\cdot y = \int e^z\cdot z\cdot dz = (\tan x - 1)\cdot e^{\tan x}\] we can say that \[ \qquad y = (\tan x - 1) + \frac{C}{e^{\tan x}} \] %
